entry.title: Day 235 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Nant TT night. I started from the top of Zorro again, however I didn't make it to the bottom. My chain started skipping and then fell off so about half way down I decided to pull over and put it back on. At that point I noticed that the chainring …
entry.content: Nant TT night. I started from the top of Zorro again, however I didn't make it to the bottom. My chain started skipping and then fell off so about half way down I decided to pull over and put it back on. At that point I noticed that the chainring had snapped. I thought about continuing but decided that I'd probably not make it up the leg burner so walked back up Zorro. Down to no bikes!

entry.content: Went back to the dentist today to get my tooth refilled. Feels a bit weird already so this could be fun again... I tried to go for a ride on the Levo but the motor/battery just wouldn't work at all so I'm going to have to book it in for warranty again. Dan has been riding a big adventure on his bike lately and is due in Aber so I offered him a place to stay. He fell off this morning and his GPS took him the wrong way a bit so he got the train from the Newtown. I picked him up from town ~8pm. I forgot to photo him. I ordered a refurbished Dyson V6 as it's cordless and really light so should be a lot easier to use and that was delivered today.

entry.content: I completed my servicing this morning. I rebled the brakes and fiddled with the forks, both now feel great. Whilst I was at it I also replaced the dropper cable and the gear cable. In other news over the past few days my toothache has been getting increasingly worse. Last night I lost quite a lot of sleep and have been in agony so I got an emergency appointment at my dentist this afternoon at 2pm. He removed the temporary filling and said that I have an abssess below the tooth, he's left the tooth open to allow the abssess to drain. Feels better already.

entry.content: Bike service time again! I did the seatpost, brakes, fork uppers and fork lowers. I also regreased a few bits. The forks now don't compress properly and the brakes feel terrible so I'll be redoing those tomorrow! I couldn't do the shock due to running out of fox float fluid so I'll be doing that once I have some.

entry.title: Day 228 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Nant TT day again on the Mega again. After a brief haitus last week, to do a bigger ride, I got back to it this evening. I decided to park at the top of Zorro this time, as it's a quicker and easier drive. It's also been raining a fair …
entry.content: Nant TT day again on the Mega again. After a brief haitus last week, to do a bigger ride, I got back to it this evening. I decided to park at the top of Zorro this time, as it's a quicker and easier drive. It's also been raining a fair bit so I knew that the moorlands would be wet and so I wanted to do that last. I felt pretty fast down Zorro, this bike is much easier to move around than the Levo is. I think that I went a bit too fast up the leg burner to begin with as my legs were suffering a little bit by Hippity Hop. Coupled with riding yesterday and the wind and the resulting time reflected it all. Just under 54 minutes which is 5 minutes slower than 2 weeks ago. 5 minutes is quite a lot!

entry.title: Day 226 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Another day off today and I had planeed to ride but I'm pretty knackered from the weekend. Getting old! I've mostly just chilled out but I've also built my server (I bought the machine from Ed's work and he gave it to me over the weekend). It's running nicely now …
entry.content: Another day off today and I had planeed to ride but I'm pretty knackered from the weekend. Getting old! I've mostly just chilled out but I've also built my server (I bought the machine from Ed's work and he gave it to me over the weekend). It's running nicely now with all of the services that I want successfully auto-starting. Working out how to get google drive syncing for blog publishing/updates was the tricky bit. I've gone for using Insync which seems pretty decent and painless. I had 2 hours of trying to work out why my entire wired network was dead - turned out to be the powerline adapater that connects the router to the rest of the house. Other than that it's been simple.

Now, back to beer.

entry.title: Day 210 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: This is basically how my gamejam has gone! For one reason or another it's only been myself and Elysia doing it and she's been at work today. I'm not a big fan of the theme - "Running out of power". We didn't want to do something generic so we decided that …
entry.content: This is basically how my gamejam has gone! For one reason or another it's only been myself and Elysia doing it and she's been at work today. I'm not a big fan of the theme - "Running out of power". We didn't want to do something generic so we decided that running out of power could be a metaphor for life getting harder or something like that. We had an idea where you play the day to day life of someone with MS, starting healthy and then ending up in a different state - varying from healthy to not very healthy. I was struggling to work out how to make this into a game, and also how to respect MS and not accidentally make it seem trivial in some way. Defold editor also kept maxing out my RAM at random! In the end I gave up and played Borderlands 2 for the rest of the day!

entry.title: Day 207 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Not much to report today but I received this letter on Saturday. Although it's only a brain scan, and I think there may be lesions in my spinal cord, it's good news! On photoing this letter I also found a second page that goes into a bit more detail, although …
entry.content: Not much to report today but I received this letter on Saturday. Although it's only a brain scan, and I think there may be lesions in my spinal cord, it's good news! On photoing this letter I also found a second page that goes into a bit more detail, although I've had to google what some of it means. The new lesion is touching the part of the brain responsible for vision so I guess that I'm quite lucky that it doesn't seem to have affected it!

entry.title: Day 198 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I last quite a lot of sleep this morning due to waking up with bad toothache. It was bad enough that it finally made go to the dentist, a private dentist due to a lack of availability at NHS dentists here. In the end I went for Portland Street dentist …
entry.content: I last quite a lot of sleep this morning due to waking up with bad toothache. It was bad enough that it finally made go to the dentist, a private dentist due to a lack of availability at NHS dentists here. In the end I went for Portland Street dentist as they had an appointment available this afternoon. Apparently I must grind my teeth badly during the night so need a mouthguard and I also need the tooth that hurts sorting. The tooth probably needs root canal, but there is a chance that I won't. The plan estimate was something of a shock to me! I've paid £65 so far and still have toothache!

entry.content: Well, I did a load of trail work today, which my legs were less than impressed about. entry.title: Day 195 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: A while ago I went for a wander through the woods that toboggan is in and found an old trail. Today I finally got round to starting to bring it back to life and, hopefully, build a top section into it. It seems that someone else has had a similar …
entry.content: A while ago I went for a wander through the woods that toboggan is in and found an old trail. Today I finally got round to starting to bring it back to life and, hopefully, build a top section into it. It seems that someone else has had a similar idea and cleared up to the second corner. I started clearing off the brash from the rest and cut out any downed trees. There's 1 bit that has a very fixed in place across the trail so I'm going to need to work out how to route around that.

entry.title: Day 190 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Legs weren't feeling great so I decided to go out on my bike for an easy one. That somehow changed very rapidly into a bit of a bigger ride than I had planned and using eco mode on the bike. In the end I rode up to Angler's Retreat via …
entry.content: Legs weren't feeling great so I decided to go out on my bike for an easy one. That somehow changed very rapidly into a bit of a bigger ride than I had planned and using eco mode on the bike. In the end I rode up to Angler's Retreat via Zorro. I very, very nearly managed the Nant-y-cagal climb but a balance mistake saw me nearly go back down the step bit over the bars instead. It was really great to ride Hockey Mask again, it's awesome. I also regained a load of my confidence for some reason. All in all, a really great ride!

entry.content:
I had a day of getting bits and pieces done today. The day started early with taking Elysia to the train station to go to her friend's wedding. I managed to fix my gears and clean all of the sealant off of my frame. I mowed a lawn and did a ton of weeding on the patio, couchgrass sucks! I hoovered the house, cleaned the kitchen a bit and, for some reason, cleaned all of the PVC and tiles in the utility. Jobs are done now at least.

For food this evening I decided to buy a piece of marinated salmon from Morrisons and have it with a load of steam veggies and jasmine rice. Not overly exciting but very nice.

entry.summary: I had to go down to Swansea for an MRI scan. It's a good job that I left an hour early as the road between Lampeter and Carmarthen had a big queue on it that wasn't moving at all. I don't know why but it did mean that I had …
entry.content:
I had to go down to Swansea for an MRI scan. It's a good job that I left an hour early as the road between Lampeter and Carmarthen had a big queue on it that wasn't moving at all. I don't know why but it did mean that I had to drive a load of singletrack roads to get around it. Anyway, MRI scan was OK. It was way shorter than normal as they only did a brain scan with contrast rather than neck/spine too.

I had thrown my bike in the car just in case I wanted to ride afterward. It was a nice day, I was in the mood and I sure didn't want to take the same route home so I decided to ride. Brechfa is almost on the way home on the different route so that's where I want. I rode the read and it was pretty great, as always.

Walk round up being a couple of hours long which I hadn't planned and legs weren't thrilled by the end! Walked some paths that I'd never been on which was cool. Clarach woods trails are just destroyed, which isn't cool. This old building was between the top of consti and the top of the waun, near the golf course.

entry.title: Day 184 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I noticed last week that the steam link was at £11.99 and I'd been looking at one for a while but been unsure it'll work with, ethernet over power, network. Just so happened that the link + a steam controller was also being bundled together for £35 so I went …
entry.content: I noticed last week that the steam link was at £11.99 and I'd been looking at one for a while but been unsure it'll work with, ethernet over power, network. Just so happened that the link + a steam controller was also being bundled together for £35 so I went for both. They arrived today. I setup the link and gave it a while with Super Meat Boy, a game where larency would matter. No issues what-so-ever, pretty impressed. The controller is also mad, the buttons are also customisable and there's even paddles that work as modifiers to make the buttons perform multiple different functions. Looking forward to being able to play PC games in my living room!

entry.title: Day 183 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I spent most of today finishing up dismantling the piano. I also went to a farm near Llanon with Elysia so that she could learn how to use a spinning wheel, she's was also lent one to learn on so you can probably guess what one photo this week will …
entry.content: I spent most of today finishing up dismantling the piano. I also went to a farm near Llanon with Elysia so that she could learn how to use a spinning wheel, she's was also lent one to learn on so you can probably guess what one photo this week will be... Anyway, the piano took me quite a long time and by the end gone was the idea of doing things sympathetically, for a start some things were glued in place. I had the chisel, hammer and wire cutters out by the end. Getting the harp out took a while, there was 1 bolt in the bottom left that wouldn't budge and I couldn't get the harp to move - something else was holding it in place. After a good while of trying to work out where the last bolt was I realised that the string pegs weren't attached to the harp, they were part of the backboard. Snip, snip, snip and the harp was moving. I used the weight of the harp to rip out the bottom left bolt and that was that. It took 2 of us to move the harp outside but it wasn't as heavy as I'd expected and from there moving the piano body was easy!

entry.title: Day 182 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I went to Myherin again today, I'm really loving it there at the moment. The weather was good and the trails were great. I think that next time I'll get down the top of Truman clean so long as I don't make any mistakes. I'd also seen a trail on …
entry.content: I went to Myherin again today, I'm really loving it there at the moment. The weather was good and the trails were great. I think that next time I'll get down the top of Truman clean so long as I don't make any mistakes. I'd also seen a trail on Strava that I'd not ridden so I checked that out. It was rooty and not rocky! It was great! I had to clear a bit of it with the saw but that was fine. I also rode the trail that I found last week but with a bit of pace and that was also brilliant. I rode the new trail a couple of times and I also worked out how to get back onto Brashy Dive which was cool. Very happy now that I know a mix of rock and dirt trails up there.

entry.title: Day 181 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: The final gravity of this batch of beer has settled at around 1.005 putting the percentage at 6-6.5%. Last week's weather has likely played hell with the yeast as the fermentation got much warmer than it should have. As it's settled I decided that I'd best siphon it …
entry.content: The final gravity of this batch of beer has settled at around 1.005 putting the percentage at 6-6.5%. Last week's weather has likely played hell with the yeast as the fermentation got much warmer than it should have. As it's settled I decided that I'd best siphon it into my plastic keg as I've run out of bottles. Sampling it there's plenty of sediment in it and the taste isn't bad but it isn't good either. It'll spend another in the airing cupboard and then it's going into the garage for a month so we'll see how it turns out...

entry.content: More dismantling! I've been wanting this piano out of the house for some time but it's seriously heavy and the layout of the house is kind of awkward so it'd be a right pain to remove. I've put it up on Facebook groups and on freecycle but no-one wants it so it's time to take it apart. I'm being sympathetic in my dismantling effort so that maybe I can convince someone that they want the body for a prop or something. So far it's been surprising modular in taking it apart, just needed to undo a few screws. Been quite interesting seeing how it all fits together and works too.

entry.content: It's about that time again, time for interim service! On the list for this service is: dropper post and replace dropper cable, air can service on shock, forks lowers, bleed brakes and then anything else that looks/feels like it's about time. I'd never done the dropper before, it was surprising easy once I managed to get the collar off. Replacing the cable was a bit more faff as it means getting the dropper out of the frame and then faffing about trying to get the cable the right length. I didn't do the forks as I'd hit the can't be arsed stage by then and I also didn't bleed the brakes. I didn't bother doing the brakes because I marched the pistons out a bit and now they feel great!

entry.title: Day 175 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I went for a ride up to Nant today, the first descent that I did was Zorro and it felt pretty terrible. Balance was off and not feeling it. At the bottom I was feeling quite dehydrated though so I drank all of my water which meant that I needed …
entry.content: I went for a ride up to Nant today, the first descent that I did was Zorro and it felt pretty terrible. Balance was off and not feeling it. At the bottom I was feeling quite dehydrated though so I drank all of my water which meant that I needed to refill from the stream. I realised that I'd never actually been down to the stream and looked down the tunnel, so that is what I did. By the top of the leg burner I was feeling much better and had a great ride for the remainder! I've kind of known for a while that being dehydrated seems to exacerbate things and this just reinforced that. Fine line though, drink too much and I'll stopping every few minutes for a wee!

He recommended that I do stretching and try to strengthen it. These resistance bands are a part of trying to strengthen it. Elysia's sister is …
entry.content: Desperate times! Resistance bands. Why? In the last visit with my neurologist he demonstrated that my hip flexors were weakened, the right one especially so. He recommended that I do stretching and try to strengthen it. These resistance bands are a part of trying to strengthen it. Elysia's sister is a physio so she asked what exercise might be good for, she recommended lying psoas with a band, as demonstrated in this video. I've combined that with a couple of other non-band exercises. Here's hoping it helps...

entry.title: Day 173 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: This actually came on Monday. It's my new sit/stand desk. I was looking at electric ones for quite a while and probably would have bought an IKEA one if delivery wasn't 35 quid and they weren't £440 anyway. After looking around for a bit I found that there are …
entry.content:
This actually came on Monday. It's my new sit/stand desk. I was looking at electric ones for quite a while and probably would have bought an IKEA one if delivery wasn't 35 quid and they weren't £440 anyway. After looking around for a bit I found that there are manual desks that operate using a winding handle. They're a fair bit cheaper than the electric ones. I wound up buying this one on Amazon. It seemed like a good size and got good reviews.

I'm very happy with it, it's definitely a good size and the height range is good. Construction was easy enough too. If I had to find any complaints then it scratches quite easily and shows up marks. My mouse also won't track on the surface!

entry.content: Today I went for a ride in the Dyfi, I wanted to ride all of the descents that I know of on the Corris side. I started off with footpath and my balance was pretty screwy, it kind of set the tone for the rest of the ride. In the end I skipped 3 descents (still managed 6) but discovered a new trail. I didn't do the other 3 as I just wasn't really enjoying myself all that much. Ho hum! I also didn't take a photo... However, some chillies are growing nicely now on this plant and I have 1 growing on the other plant, that one looks kinda cool - it's a bruised colour.

entry.title: Day 167 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I went for a ride this evening, up to nant. I decided to play a new game of pedalling as much as I want at the start of a trail but as soon as I stop pedalling that's it, no more pedalling allowed. Got to keep things interesting somehow... My …
entry.content:
I went for a ride this evening, up to nant. I decided to play a new game of pedalling as much as I want at the start of a trail but as soon as I stop pedalling that's it, no more pedalling allowed. Got to keep things interesting somehow... My balance was noticeably off a bit which added an extra bit of challenge to the mix. I had a brief play in the skills area too, I couldn't really be bothered to stop for a photo though.

When I got home I decided to make a thai red curry. The reason why I haven't for a good while is that it requires coconut milk. I decided sod it, how much saturated fat can coconut milk have in it? Well, boy was I surprised. Even the reduced fat version had 60g of saturated fat per can. I was committed to the idea so I did it anyway but I'm going to be looking into alternatives...

entry.title: Day 165 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: This evening I went for a ride on the Levo. It was going great, toboggan was riding great and the weather was nice. I decided to head out the top of nant on the Syfydin route. As I climbed up to the Bont Goch descent I was trying to choose …
entry.content:
This evening I went for a ride on the Levo. It was going great, toboggan was riding great and the weather was nice. I decided to head out the top of nant on the Syfydin route. As I climbed up to the Bont Goch descent I was trying to choose between it and the bridleway. In the end I decided to take the Bont Goch descent, might have been a mistake! There was immediately a fair bit of water erosion and picking a good line was difficult. After I rounded the first left hander and was approaching warp speed I spotted a really big hole, too late. I slammed on the brakes but no way was I near to stopping, straight into the hole and very, very, luckily just about out the other side. I wound up running whilst still straddling the bike and I totally bottomed out my forks. Feel quite lucky I got away with it.

About 3/4 of the way down the descent I hucked off some rocks and just after I landed I felt the rear wheel buck out as I hit a big rock. Very soon after I realised I had a total flat. Annoying. Oh well, fit a new tube. Won't go up properly. Has a hole in it. I carry puncture repair stuff so I tried to repair it but no luck. Wound up riding the whole way home on a flat, think I might need a new tyre now :(

entry.content: As trying to get chillies to grow from seed is taking a while and is a bit trial and error I decided to cheat and buy a couple of adult plants. I bought a Demon Red plant and a Twilight plant from South Devon chilli farm. They arrived last Thursday but I only had time to unpackage them and put them in the porch. They're looking a bit sad in the photo but I've since given them a good glug of water each and they're looking happy again now. The weather here has been terrible lately so I think that I'll put them in the airing cupboard overnight to keep the compost warm. There's already a couple of chillies starting to grow on the Twilight too :).

entry.title: Day 152 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: 6 months into the year. That's gone quickly. I've not been sleeping right for a while now. My jawbone is telling me my deep sleep amount is well down, the majority of nights under 30 minutes. Whilst I take the figure itself with a pinch of salt I feel reasonably …
entry.content: 6 months into the year. That's gone quickly. I've not been sleeping right for a while now. My jawbone is telling me my deep sleep amount is well down, the majority of nights under 30 minutes. Whilst I take the figure itself with a pinch of salt I feel reasonably confident in believing the relative amounts over the months. It's now way down compared to what I was getting in March. It's hit the point where it is impacting on my well-being as I feel too tired in the evenings to do anything. I've decided I've got to do something about it, including throwing a bit of money at it. I don't want to go down the drugs route though. I've spent a bit of money on a blackout blind which should come next week and I'm trying to cut out screen time after 10 and then stretch/read until 11 when I'll go to sleep and then get up at 7. Bit of strictish routine should help I think. Until the black blind comes I have a makeshift solution... I got over double the amount of deep sleep as usual night but 1 night isn't a large enough sample size.

entry.title: Day 151 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I got home and decided to check on the veggie patch, the mixed salad bits are doing well! They've grown considerably since I last checked them. I had to do a spot of weeding as there were a couple of dandelions sprouting up. In hindsight I maybe should left them …
entry.content:
I got home and decided to check on the veggie patch, the mixed salad bits are doing well! They've grown considerably since I last checked them. I had to do a spot of weeding as there were a couple of dandelions sprouting up. In hindsight I maybe should left them and just ate them too but I was a bit worried they'd steal resources from the other plants. I was in a bit of a productive mood so I also went to the garden centre to pick up some more top soil, and I bought a bell pepper plant whilst I was there - because why not. I want to get some chilli plants as I seem to be incapable of growing from seed but they don't sell those.

Using the top soil I finally finished filling in the holes in the lawn and also sowed some grass seed. So today's photo is the lawn as it stands at the moment, I'm hoping in a couple of months time to have an after shot with grass growing!

entry.title: Day 146 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Earlier in the week I booked today off as the forecast looked great. The forecast was correct! I'd planned to do a "sea to summit to sea" ride, something that's been on my radar since Dave and Pete rode it last year's solstice. The summit being Pumlumon, the nearest mountain …
entry.content:
Earlier in the week I booked today off as the forecast looked great. The forecast was correct! I'd planned to do a "sea to summit to sea" ride, something that's been on my radar since Dave and Pete rode it last year's solstice. The summit being Pumlumon, the nearest mountain to aber. I had my garmin loaded up with the route and set out at about 9am as a) I had a family bbq I wanted to attend in the evening and b) it's aber cycle fest weekend so some of the roads were closed later in the day.

The route I rode up to nant was actually a new one on me. From there it was Joe's back garden to the bottom climb up to the summit. THe climb was going well until the fireroad just ended. Dave had mentioned a hike a bike but I had hoped that I'd be OK on ebike. No, it really was hike a bike. I pushed through reasonably thick trees for a bit until deciding that enough was enough and it was time to turn back. I found a stream and started following that briefly which bought me out into a bit of a cleared section. It was where I was meant to be, it was where the track on the map was. There was no track, just grassy, tussocky bog for the most part but it was clear and it was pushable. After a while I came across the footpath up Pumlumon, it was fireroad. I was happy. My legs were somewhat not.

I stuck the bike in turbo as there was plenty of battery power left and my legs were struggling after the hike a bike. The fireroad ran out after a bit and the route became grass, but rideable, to the summit. A new view for me! The route back down was basically a steepish field with lots of tussocks. A bit boring to be honest. It dropped me back down at Nant-y-moch. I made it home in time to drive to Oswestry and partake in the BBQ which was also cool!

entry.title: Day 135 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: We went down to Swansea today to go to Morriston Hospital for my yearly appointment with my neurologist. Parking was, as usual, awful. There were cars everywhere, luckily we managed to pull into a not a space really quickly. We arrived a bit early as I wanted to leave a …
entry.content:
We went down to Swansea today to go to Morriston Hospital for my yearly appointment with my neurologist. Parking was, as usual, awful. There were cars everywhere, luckily we managed to pull into a not a space really quickly. We arrived a bit early as I wanted to leave a bit of buffer time as it's a 1hr45 drive but I was seen at pretty much bang on 11:30 and was done by 11:45! We discussed my meds and my lymphocyte count. If my lymphocyte count gets too low then they'll pull me off the meds as the, very rare, occurences of PML have occured with low lymphocyte counts. Mine was surprisingly high, the count was normal. That's good!

I also asked him about the OMS diet. He had heard of it. He said that it can't hurt and that they're OK with it. It's a good idea to cut down on saturated fat and replace it with poly-unsaturated, for anybody. He also said it may help but because it's healthy rather than some magic bullet combination of foods. He said as a general rule, don't cut out any food groups. My takeaway from it was that I'll keep following the diet but not treat it as gospel. I may, quite rarely, eat some white meat/game. I'm going to keep off dairy but I'm going to sometimes eat cake and things like that (I'm aware they have dairy in), not often but sometimes.

After chatting for a bit we moved onto tests. I think that he said that my reflexes are brisk. My hip flexors are definitely weakened and my legs are over-toned which causes them to be stiff. I must find hip flexor exercises to try build up whatever muscles are still good to try to compensate I think.

After the hospital visit we went to see George and Poppy and their new addition to the family, Finn. It was really nice to see them and catch up and to also meet Finn. Finn would have made for a much better photo too! Next time we'll make the visit a bit longer.

entry.title: Day 133 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I did a rideout on the mega today, possibly the last I'm going to do on it. The ride started out well, I felt good. By midway up the leg burner my legs were starting to go into limp mode a bit and were starting to hurt. By the visitor …
entry.content:
I did a rideout on the mega today, possibly the last I'm going to do on it. The ride started out well, I felt good. By midway up the leg burner my legs were starting to go into limp mode a bit and were starting to hurt. By the visitor centre I was about ready to sell my bike. It's difficult to explain how my legs feel but it's not good and it's frustrating. I just can't ride fast and it has a knock on effect into the descents too as I can't pedal out of the saddle when they're at all tired. Should get the ebike back mid week and I'm really looking forward to that. I'm still going to ride the mega, it's a fun bike. I think I'll probably keep rides on it below 20km though.

I was in no mood for taking photos so here's my tea instead. I followed this recipe and had chilli, garlic and tomato mussels with some homemade 50% wholemeal buns, salad and chips. It was actually rather a lot of food!

entry.title: Day 132 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: A visit to Bronglais. Just a routine appointment with the MS nurse, nothing exciting! The hospital is a bit less attractive from this side. I only had to wait 5-10 minutes before being seen (and I was 5 mins early anyway) which was great. We quickly realised that actually the …
entry.content: A visit to Bronglais. Just a routine appointment with the MS nurse, nothing exciting! The hospital is a bit less attractive from this side. I only had to wait 5-10 minutes before being seen (and I was 5 mins early anyway) which was great. We quickly realised that actually the appointment I had should have been 3 months previous but due to some administrative error it'd been missed. Explains why I had an appointment today and I have one in Swansea on Monday. Bonus is that I had bloods taken today (with no wait at all) so hopefully won't need them taken on Monday. Last time I had bloods taken in Swansea there was a 2 hour wait, so I'm quite happy that I should be able to avoid that!

entry.title: Day 127 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I had so much fun yesterday that I went back to the same trails today, although I didn't do part of the loop. I did one descent a couple of times and I had a good explore. It was rad. On my way back I also pushed up something that …
entry.content:
I had so much fun yesterday that I went back to the same trails today, although I didn't do part of the loop. I did one descent a couple of times and I had a good explore. It was rad. On my way back I also pushed up something that I thought would be a short bit of overgrown, old track. It wasn't, it's a pretty full on downhill track! I pushed up it quite a way but then it got too steep. I still need to find the top! On the way back down I was having a fun but scary time. Then, bang! I was down. I wasn't entirely sure what happened but I fell off at the bottom of a chute into a corner. On the push up I spotted a stump in the chute that I thought was perfect for grabbing a pedal. Turns out, it was! A few cuts and bruises but all good.

I also decided to have a bit of a play with my phone camera so here's a stream.

entry.title: Day 126 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I actually had quite a busy day today. I woke up quite late at 9:15 having got around 10 hours of sleep! I cleaned up and photo'd some bike bits that I want to sell. Just as I finished doing that Elysia rang me and asked if I wanted …
entry.content:
I actually had quite a busy day today. I woke up quite late at 9:15 having got around 10 hours of sleep! I cleaned up and photo'd some bike bits that I want to sell. Just as I finished doing that Elysia rang me and asked if I wanted to go for lunch with her. Yes, yes I did. We went to Baravin, I was disappointed to see that my favourite had been taken off the menu but the soup of the day was carrot and coriander with sourdough bread. So I went for that and it was very nice, I also had a cold brew coffee - I always forget how nice that is. In the afternoon I spent most of the time doing gamebuildr but as the evening approached I decided that I wanted to ride my bike. I really couldn't get enthused about riding nant. I remembered that the Ystwyth ride just gone went somewhere that I'd not ridden before, starting from tre-ddol which is a short drive away. I loaded the route onto my garmin in the hope that the battery would last the ride and set out. Sorted!

I got there to find my rear flat completely flat and the garmin refusing to load the route. I shoved some air in the tyre and had a bit of a fiddle and it seemed to be holding air and I set out in the hope that the garmin would sort itself out. I was straight onto a dirt trail, dirt - yes! I was really hoping for dirt trails rather than rocky ones. Halfway up the first (singletrack!) climb my garmin started working. Things were looking up! The loop was really fun, the descents were great and mostly techy. There were some fantastic views over the estuary from on the top. A route that I'll be doing again for sure and I might try to find some more stuff over there too. My legs now have that after exercise glowing feeling, I can't remember the last time I felt this. They usually just have a deep, dull ache!

entry.title: Day 123 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Another standard day. This evening I cleared out what used to be my office but has become a bit of a storage room. I mostly just moved stuff that belongs outside into the garage and then tidied up to leave some space and make the room a room again. My …
entry.content:
Another standard day. This evening I cleared out what used to be my office but has become a bit of a storage room. I mostly just moved stuff that belongs outside into the garage and then tidied up to leave some space and make the room a room again. My reasoning for doing this is to give me some clear space for doing stretches and a small amount of weight stuffs. I also wrote down all of my stretches as I have a habit of forgetting a couple of them and this way I can see them all and just follow the order.

I try to hold each stretch for 15 seconds but I felt like the routine was taking far longer than it should have been. As I just judge how long to hold them based on doing 15 slow breaths I decided to actually time a couple of the stretches. Turns out I hold each for 30-45 seconds, no bad thing I think!

entry.title: Day 120 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: The day has rolled round and it's been the Dyfi Enduro. The difference this year was that there were 2 routes, the enduro and the bach. The enduro was 55km and the bach 40km, they were similar routes but the bach just cut a few bits out. Looking at the …
entry.content:
The day has rolled round and it's been the Dyfi Enduro. The difference this year was that there were 2 routes, the enduro and the bach. The enduro was 55km and the bach 40km, they were similar routes but the bach just cut a few bits out. Looking at the map of the routes we'd kind of decided to do the enduro but cut out 1 section which has nothing much fun in it. We'd also spotted a slight shortcut that I could take to cut out the single track climb as I was a bit concerned I'd end up walking it and my legs would give up on life.

We arrived ~9:30, signed on, got ready and tried to find Taylor. We were at the back of the queue and a brief phone call told us that he was at the front. We wound up starting roughly mid pack with a view to catch him up if he took it steady. We started off and as we were riding along the road I was feeling pretty good but very shortly after we hit the first fireroad I could feel that my legs weren't going to be good. I was riding slowly and I couldn't go any faster. My legs weren't shaking or anything they were just saying no. I felt like I was moving in slow motion for most of the climbs. It was almost like a disconnect between brain and legs, my brain would say push harder/faster and my legs would say yes but then they just wouldn't.

The others waited for me at the top of the climbs and part way up them too which was nice as it meant I wasn't always alone on them thinking about how bad my legs were being. On each climb I decided that I was packing it in at the top. At the top of each climb I decided that there was no way I wasn't riding the descent. At the bottom of the descents adrenaline would be pumping and I'd be feeling good again! A vicious cycle.

All of the descents were great fun and I managed to stay stood up on them. I rode my own ride on a few of them, on elephant Bean and I decided to cut off and do the alternative line as the main trail was a big queue. Sadly I decided to skip world cup. The climb from world cup to the feed station is long and I just didn't feel like it was going to be a good idea. I'd just gone over the bars onto bedrock on Caban Coch too so my upper body was hurting in addition to my legs. I skipped a section after the feed station which has a quite long descent and a bit of climbing and I also skipped goshawk as that had the single track climb up to it, luckily the descent before has a sneak shortcut out of it to the bottom of goshawk. As such I'd left the others behind so I decided to just crack on up to 3in1. On the climb couple of riders who were pushing their bikes managed to catch up with me whilst I was actually riding, "sorry mate, we slowed down a bit because we didn't want to demotivate you but...". Had to laugh! I rode the single track just off of 3in1 which was great, grabbed my beer at the bottom and waited for the others before crossing the finish line and spinning back down to Mach. It didn't even rain for the whole ride!

Bean n Steph asked me to take a photo of them at the finish line in Mach and I was taking the photo who appeared from the crowd behind them? It was Taylor! He'd not hung around on the ride and had put in a good time and then just waited for us to finish. It was good to see him and look at his new bike too.

I was a good day out, I didn't enjoy some of it and I really enjoyed some other bits of it. I'm disappointed that I didn't get to ride world cup but I think it was for the best. Unless things change dramatically for the better then this will probably be my last dyfi on a non-ebike so I'm really glad that I did it and got the mug. I'm also grateful that the others waited for me as I really was on a go-slow. We finished off the day by eating slow cooked chilli, drinking beer and watching the DH world cup. Things could certainly be far, far worse!

entry.title: Day 117 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: New phone! I decided to buy a new phone because the charging port on my moto g3 has come to be quite loose. Cables have to be wiggled around to get them to engage and the slightest knock knocks them out. Not great, really annoying when using the phone as …
entry.content:
New phone! I decided to buy a new phone because the charging port on my moto g3 has come to be quite loose. Cables have to be wiggled around to get them to engage and the slightest knock knocks them out. Not great, really annoying when using the phone as a satnav and charging at the same time. Anyway, I was looking at phones when I realised that my phone is covered by 2 year EU warranty. Sorted! I emailed Amazon to say that I'd like a repair on warranty. They replied with no repair, no replacement but they'd give me a full refund if I returned it. Er, deal!

Because I'd now have the money from that phone I decided to spend a little more money than I would have otherwise. I spent a good while looking at phones and they all seemed to have something wrong with them. The obvious choice was the Oneplusthree but it was a bit big and a bit more money than I wanted to spend. I came upon the Xiaomi Mi5, which seemed to tick all my boxes. It is not easy to get hold of in the UK, it's popular in China and India. I found one Uk seller, on ebay - I wanted a UK seller so I'd have warranty.

When it came I tried to update it and quite quickly came to discover that it had an unofficial rom on it. One that's a bit dodgy and possibly had malware. Putting a new rom on was pretty simple but a bit of a faff. To begin with the bootloader must be unlocked but to do that you need the miui guys to unlock it via your mi account. It's just a form to fill in and they actually granted me access overnight. Next issue, no Windows on any of my machines. Luckily, Elysia has a Windows install on her mac. That ran out of space. In the end I grabbed a windows 7 VM, unlocked the phone, flashed miui 8 (android 7) onto it and relocked it. It needs locking for things like android pay to work. Miui has some neat features like one handed mode and I'm very happy with it now I have it set up with nova launcher and a few things set to how I want.

entry.title: Day 112 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: This weekend is Ludum Dare #38 gamejam. I'm taking part with Dirty Casuals. Early this morning the theme was released - "A Small World", not a great theme IMO but that's what was voted for. After some discussion we decided to make a game where you play as pluto battling to …
entry.content: This weekend is Ludum Dare #38 gamejam. I'm taking part with Dirty Casuals. Early this morning the theme was released - "A Small World", not a great theme IMO but that's what was voted for. After some discussion we decided to make a game where you play as pluto battling to regain the title of being a planet. Initially we set it up to be like pong but we pulled the camera out a bit to enable 360 degree paddle movement. The idea is to just destroy the other planets by making the ball hit the planets, the asteroids provide extra gravity effects on the ball to things interesting. You can play the game at LD38-A-Small_world.

entry.title: Day 110 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: This evening I decided to give my mega shock a long, long, long overdue strip down and proper service. I've had the seal/orings kit for quite a while but didn't have the tools for removal of the aip cap and the adapter to reinflate the shock. I built the …
entry.content:
This evening I decided to give my mega shock a long, long, long overdue strip down and proper service. I've had the seal/orings kit for quite a while but didn't have the tools for removal of the aip cap and the adapter to reinflate the shock. I built the cap removal tool and the adapter came in the post earlier this week.

All did not go to plan. No matter what I tried I could not get the air can to come apart. I tried strap wrenches, inner tubes and even tape + molgrips. Nope!

entry.content: I was still off work today and decided that I'd have a nice relaxing day, maybe play some video games. I had a quite productive day instead. I finally went to the tip with all of the fir tree that I chopped down. I cleared weeds and soil from the gaps between the slabs on the patio and brushed the patio. I went to the garden centre with Elysia to pick up some top soil and compost, and also had a coffee there. I started filling in the big holes in my lawn with said top soil, I'm going to need more. I'm also going to need to remember to buy grass seed. I hoed the veggie patch and a couple of the smaller little bits in the patio and mixed some compost into them. I planted some mint, basil and holy basil, hopefully they'll grow! I slow cooked a chili and rearranged some of the kitchen. I also did some gamebuildr and had a gamebuildr meeting. Not such a relaxing day after all!

entry.title: Day 107 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: As my mega is most definitely out of action I decided to try go for a ride on the ebike again. I knew where I want to go, just not how I wanted to get there or back. I set off out toward Capel Dewi and the bike seemed to …
entry.content:
As my mega is most definitely out of action I decided to try go for a ride on the ebike again. I knew where I want to go, just not how I wanted to get there or back. I set off out toward Capel Dewi and the bike seemed to be behaving, I decided that I was going to head to the top of nant via Zorro. Once at the top of Nant I had a few options on which way to go but I decided to just follow the Syfydrin trail out to Nant-y-moch and then keep following the road to Nant y cagal. At that point I decided to try ride up the steep techy climb as a) it's shorter than the road round and b) I was on an ebike. I also managed it, but not quite. From there I just followed my usual way out to the Mach 3 loop and The Chute. It was a nice clear day and the views were good. I even got treated to a close up of a kite. The chute was, as always, really fun.

I was a bit torn about which way to head home, I'm not a big fan of Scaletrix but I knew that following the Mach 3 and then heading back the way I came would involve lifting over more gates than I wanted. I'd already had to lift over quite a few. I devised a plan to head to Hyddgen sheds but to keep going down the side of Nant-y-moch rather than go along Scaletrix. After that I decided to ride the field section of Joe's Back Garden backward, something that I'd never done before. Something that I'm in no rush to do again. It wasn't bad or anything, it just wasn't especially exciting either. Ice rink, toboggan and home. Ebike decided to stop working on the final climb up to my house which wasn't great but manageable. All in managed to do 75km, a nice day out!

entry.title: Day 106 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: As I've entered the dyfi enduro I decided that I'd best do a long ride on the mega today to test my legs. I also fitted a dinner plate cassette (11-42) yesterday so wanted to try it. I set out and got up the mountain road feeling pretty good and …
entry.content: As I've entered the dyfi enduro I decided that I'd best do a long ride on the mega today to test my legs. I also fitted a dinner plate cassette (11-42) yesterday so wanted to try it. I set out and got up the mountain road feeling pretty good and was even getting up ice rink just fine, I managed the difficult corner no worries. Just after that corner though, disaster struck. I pedalled and there was a very fast clicking noise and no movement. "That sounds like the freehub slipping" I thought. Tried to pedal again, same thing. Yup, the freehub was not engaging under any load at all. Great. I was 12km from home so it took me 2 hours to walk/scoot it. I dropped my saddle right down and removed the pedals so that I could scoot along on the flat fireroads/backroads. It's not much fun walking on roads with neither pavement or verge. It reminded me just how much rubbish there is on roadsides - especially busy roads but quiet roads too, it's quite depressing really.

entry.title: Day 105 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Went for a ride on my ebike today. When I started I felt like changing mode wasn't doing anything and that eco mode was giving far too much assist. I ignored it thinking maybe it was in my head or something. After a few km the motor started assisting me …
entry.content:
Went for a ride on my ebike today. When I started I felt like changing mode wasn't doing anything and that eco mode was giving far too much assist. I ignored it thinking maybe it was in my head or something. After a few km the motor started assisting me on half of the crank rotation but cutting out for the other half. I knew that something wasn't right at this point and pulled over to check the specialized app. Yup, 2 errors showing on the motor. Damn. Shortly after the motor cut out completely. I played about turning the battery on and off a few times and got the motor working a bit so cut the ride short. On getting home the app was reporting all OK. Sods law.

Summit cycles handled my warranty claim on the battery so when I got home I popped back in. I needed a new chain and a couple of gear cables anyway. I wasn't sure it was going to be worth trying for another warranty claim with an intermittent issue but I had a chat with them anyway. Apparently they now have all of the tools to perform diagnostics there so I'm going to drop my bike in on Tuesday and hopefully they can find something. I have screenshots of the app reporting errors on my phone too.

entry.content:
I totally forgot to take a photo today but I've just remembered so I'm resorting to a backup idea. I've previously mentioned using my fitbit UP3 for sleep tracking so here's a screenshot of yesterday's tracking data. As well as this data if I were to scroll down there's a graph of my passive heart rate overnight and my resting heart rate for the last 7 days against length of sleep each day.
My target sleep is 7hr30, not for any specific reason other than it sounds reasonable. So I managed to hit 102% of that target, I started to go to sleep at 23:23 and I woke up properly at 07:41. The rest is quite self explanatory, those 2 wake ups were both to go to the toilet.

entry.title: Day 98 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: As the ebike is still off for warranty I decided to head out on my mega today. The weather was really nice (I actually sunburnt) and I fancied toboggan and the secret descent. I spent a while trying to get round the bottom corner on toboggan and I finally managed …
entry.content:
As the ebike is still off for warranty I decided to head out on my mega today. The weather was really nice (I actually sunburnt) and I fancied toboggan and the secret descent. I spent a while trying to get round the bottom corner on toboggan and I finally managed it! I don't think it's going to be something I'm consistent at but at least I know I can do it. As an added bonus I also found my lost glove just sat on the outside of one of the corners. The mega is definitely easier to control on steep stuff. I rode the usual top of nant to the visitor centre where I had a coffee and bumped into someone from work so had a chat too. Secret descent was riding amazingly grippy and fast so I decided to also go a different way home. A bridleway along the rheidol valley that I'd only ridden once before. I now remember why... It'd probably be quite nice if sections weren't churned up by horses to the point of being unrideable but it was a bit of an adventure anyway and something a bit different.
Trying to decide on an image has been tricky as I took quite a few but I quite like the colours in this one and it's unlikely to be something I see again anytime soon.

entry.content: Liam managed to talk me into driving into town and going to Ultracomida for lunch. It's a great food shop with a tapas restaurant and they also do take out baguettes. I had a tuna and piquante peppers with plenty of olive oil. It was very nice and their bread is excellent.

entry.content: Today I had an appointment with urodynamics. The appointment was at 9:40 so I rode over and got to the waiting room at 9:35. This was the first time that I've not been straight in. I had to wait less than 10 minutes and I was in. Straight away she did a bladder scan and I measured 12ml which is good. After that we had a very brief chat and I left, simple! I was out by 9:55!

entry.title: Day 95 - photo a day
entry.summary: I finished work at 4 and decided that I fancied a ride, but didnt want to be out for hours so went out on the roadrat. I had a plan that I wanted to ride out down the Rheidol valley then cross the river and ride back on the bridleway …
entry.content: I finished work at 4 and decided that I fancied a ride, but didnt want to be out for hours so went out on the roadrat. I had a plan that I wanted to ride out down the Rheidol valley then cross the river and ride back on the bridleway, I've only ridden the bridleway once before. I took a bit of a wrong turned and rode down a muddy track churned up by horses so thought I might be on the right path. I wasn't, I realised that when I came to this river crossing, not a shallow river. I backtracked and just rode the road up the valley side, which is rather steep!

entry.content: I wasn't feeling great today but I had a package due to be delivered there so headed in to work. In the end I took the afternoon off as the package was delivered. The package - some new pedals. Spank spoons. They're nice and big at 110x100mm, they actually come in 3 sizes; 110, 100, 90 for different sized feet. I'm not entirely sure why they come without the pins fitted but they do come with an allen key, wrench, and pins. I'm looking forward to pedals that don't rattle, squeak and aren't missing 2 pins that can't be replaced due to the thread being stripped!

entry.content: I spend this morning sorting out the front lawn, mowing edging etc... First time is always the worst but hopefully I've made the job easier for future me. Paul and I went riding in the afternoon aiming to ride out to the chute but time was getting on a bit by the time we got to Angler's Retreat so we decided to ride the figure of 8 loop. I had the cunning idea of showing Paul the extraction track, turns out that loggers have been round those parts and the flat was an absolute mess of deep, deep mud. So that was hard going. I also had the cunning idea that we could try the hairdressers descents on the return. Well, that was also deep, deep mud. Hard going. We got home just before sunset so probably good that we didn't head to the chute.

entry.title: Day 70 - photo a day
entry.summary: Today I went to the Dyfi forest with Paul and a work colleague, Ioan. Upon arriving in the car park I turned on my bike to find that it hadn't been charged - the plug socket must have been turned off. Well, that wasn't going to stop me so we threw …
entry.content:
Today I went to the Dyfi forest with Paul and a work colleague, Ioan. Upon arriving in the car park I turned on my bike to find that it hadn't been charged - the plug socket must have been turned off. Well, that wasn't going to stop me so we threw the battery in the car and I endeavoured to ride a 20kg bike. I really didn't expect my legs to be in a good state by the top of the first climb. They were fine for almost all of the ride though! This really, really surprised me and I'm not sure why they held up so well. My general fitness also seems to be pretty decent, I wasn't blowing up on any of the climbs and wasn't going really slow either. We managed around 17 miles with 1000 metres of elevation so not exactly an easy ride either.

What I didn't do was take a photo, d'oh! So, here's one of yesterday evening's handywork!

entry.title: Day 69 - photo a day
entry.summary: Following on from yesterday's escapade into gardening, today I went from work to Charlies stores to buy a lawn aerator. My rear lawn is basically becoming a bog and moss is slowly taking over from grass. A friend suggested aerating it, the tool is only a tenner so I figured …
entry.content:
Following on from yesterday's escapade into gardening, today I went from work to Charlies stores to buy a lawn aerator. My rear lawn is basically becoming a bog and moss is slowly taking over from grass. A friend suggested aerating it, the tool is only a tenner so I figured it was worth a go. Unfortunately the problem with places like Charlies is that it's impossible to go in and only come out with what you went in for. So I now also have a new bow saw and a pair of gardening gloves (my old ones were full of holes, not great for pulling brambles). Still, less than 15 quid spent so not too bad!

The lawn is now full of holes so hopefully that'll help. I also removed another little shrub and started work on the trees. I've taken one down by chopping off all of the fronds individually so I can actually dispose of them, I still need to cut out more of the trunk. That'll be tough going. Certainly already looks better in my opinion.

There are currently a few shrubs, 2 gravel patches and 2 trees all which I want to take out. OK, I'm not going to take out the trees I'm just going to cut them down quite low on the trunk. In place of all of these things I'm going to plant various herbs, I want the trees gone to try open things up a bit as they're a bit commandeering.

So this evening I started by removing the biggest of the shrubs which took me a good couple of hours and now my garden waste bag is full again. First job done though, woo!

I figured that these days don't come often at the moment so got to go for it! I had a great ride -felt really quick on the descents which strava seems to agree with, a few PRs there. The weather stayed nice and I didn't really need lights either, I just turned on my little "be seen" ones. I also managed to get the bike battery down to 7% which is the first time that I've got it below 10%. It seems to beep a lot and cut the motor out to remind you that you're running low on power which is pretty exciting going uphill!

entry.title: Day 66 - photo a day
entry.summary: Tonight I had a technical meeting with Boomer about moving our work to a more agile approach, from pretty much ad hoc. We met in Brynamlwg which is the only pub at the top of the hill, it used to be members only but is now open to all. It's …
entry.content:
Tonight I had a technical meeting with Boomer about moving our work to a more agile approach, from pretty much ad hoc. We met in Brynamlwg which is the only pub at the top of the hill, it used to be members only but is now open to all. It's a nice enough place, feels like a proper pub and the staff are friendly. The beer prices are slightly less friendly at £3.50 a bottle but I guess being the only pub up here they can do that. The only other bars are the union and the art centre, the union has sticky floors and is, obviously, very studenty. I don't imagine the art centre being any cheaper.

We're going to try adopt a kanban meets scrum approach, something akin to scumban but maybe a bit less formal and scrum-esque. There's no review with stakeholders, because there are none, but we will do planning and retrospective albeit in the same meeting. Scrums are a no-go, we work independent ad-hoc hours and they're probably just not necessary for us as we have a really good line of communication and discuss everything anyway. I guess that we are loosely following scrum but we've cut it back a bit to suit our needs.

Luckily, the machine will do dough, including raising time etc... So I decided to try make some focaccia. The machine did the hard work and I just had to shove ingredients in the pan and leave it until ready. Once ready I just put the dough in a pan and stretched it to fit using my hands, then baked. I think I left it slightly too long because the outside has gone slightly hard rather than it all being soft but the inside is nice, light and soft. It tastes a bit bland but that's down to the ingredients and this being a first time so plenty of space for improvements.

I decided that I was going regardless and I had a really fun ride, fun until I hit the road home anyway. I PR'd a couple of descents and wasn't far off my PRs on a lot of others, I also had a play in the skills area to see how the ebike was to ride there. It was fine, I did a couple of laps of the middle jumps and a couple of laps of the pump track and it felt good on both. That means trouble for the mega! The reason the road home wasn't much fun was because by that point my hands and feet were freezing.

It was too cold/wet to stop for a photo so instead here's a screengrab from the specialized app. The charts tab has loads more information about things such as my power output during the ride, the bikes power output during the ride, speed, elevation etc... As can be seen I used a decent whack of my 460Wh the battery gives me but I was in turbo (50%) mode for the entire ride so no surprise there.

entry.title: GalliumOS wifi stopped working
entry.summary: I just fixed my chromebook (seems that the fuse in the charger had gone, so simple fix) which runs GalliumOS but on booting the wifi had stopped working. This isn't the first time that it's happened and I've fixed it before so I knew that to do. Took me a …
entry.content:
I just fixed my chromebook (seems that the fuse in the charger had gone, so simple fix) which runs GalliumOS but on booting the wifi had stopped working. This isn't the first time that it's happened and I've fixed it before so I knew that to do. Took me a while to work out last time though, lots of pulling error from dmeg and googling. I just thought that I'd make a note in case it helps someone else or I forget... It seems to be when the battery has totally drained.

The fix is pretty simple, take a look at your clock. For me this issue has always been that the clock has jumped ahead to the year 2154 which has somehow screwed up the wifi, could be messing up crypto stuff I guess? Anyway, setting the clock to manual and resetting back to today fixes it for me. Once the wifi reconnects I can set it back to sync the clock to a remote server. Seems a bit catch-22, the wifi can't connect because the date is totally invalid and the clock can't set itself because the wifi is down.

entry.title: Adding thumbnails
entry.summary: I sent a link to this blog to my mate and commented that github pages were a bit slow to serve it. He replied ""shouldn't be, github pages are usually pretty snappy", he then went on to say "however, you are linking to your full sized images on the index …
entry.content:
I sent a link to this blog to my mate and commented that github pages were a bit slow to serve it. He replied ""shouldn't be, github pages are usually pretty snappy", he then went on to say "however, you are linking to your full sized images on the index page". Ah, oops! Good point that... He sent me a link to a script that he'd used for generating thumbnails from existing images so I decided that I'd just hack on that and change it to my needs. Before doing that, I decided to have a bit of a Google for pelican thumbnails - it didn't seem to me that I'd be the first person to be doing this. I discovered pelican thumbnailer which looked ideal to me.

Armed with the thumbnailer I did some testing. Yup, it generated thumbnails from my images, great! The next step was linking to these images from my posts, I decided the simple way to do this was to add a new metadata field to my posts called "Thumbnail: " just containing the path to where the thumbnail should be once generated. Well, I wasn't going to do this manually was I? I wrote a little script to find the first image in my markdown (if any) and then take the path and add a new line as detailed above. Bit of testing and all looked good. As can be seen in my photo a day posts the links work and the index page is loading much faster, at time of testing: 7.7mb down to 232kb!

entry.title: Automating pelican
entry.summary: So following on my post about moving back to pelican I needed to automate some stuff. Google wasn't quite giving me the answers that I wanted. What I wanted was a full end to end automation process, i.e. I write a post, it appears on my blog. I did …
entry.content:
So following on my post about moving back to pelican I needed to automate some stuff. Google wasn't quite giving me the answers that I wanted. What I wanted was a full end to end automation process, i.e. I write a post, it appears on my blog. I did a bit of thinking and decided there were 2 steps to this:

  • Source content and pelican creation of output
  • Publishing the output to github

Starting at the beginning then, I have my output folder setup as its own github repo at http://chvck.github.io, the rest of the blog setup and the theme will go into another repo which will have the content and output folders ignored (I'll explain why the content is ignored later).

To publish the output it seemed pretty obvious that I needed to have some sort of git auto commit folder watcher. There are a few git auto-commit hits on google so one of those plus a post-commit hook to push was my first idea. But, then I found gitwatch which is a handy script that handles all of this for me. Worth noting, I have a ssh key stored with ssh-agent so I don't need to enter a password to push. OK cool, so now when my output folder is updated then it gets published. Rad!

Next step, and this one was tricker, was to work out how to automate the output generation. Well, pelican has a -r switch which means that it monitors the content directory for changes. OK cool, that's easy. Problem for me was that I didn't want my content directory to simply be a directory on my local filesystem, this would mean I could only post from my PC. I also wanted to be able to easily post from my mobile (and easily add images). Hey, google drive support is now kinda built into some linux distros. Cool! No, not so great. Whilst it is built in it's not great. For me it was really, really slow and it also doesn't do offline sync i.e. it won't update a local copy of something until you open it (well, containing folder). Hmm.

Then I found overgrive which claims to do what the official google drive apps do on windows/macos. For $4.99 I figured it was worth a go (turns out there's a free 14 day trial too, didn't know that though) and it's good. It's fast and it does offline sync... great! Next up I put all of my current content into a dir on google drive and then I symlinked that folder as my pelican content directory. Using the -r switch in pelican I now have automated generation. So that's generation and publishing sorted. Rad!

Final piece of the puzzle is something that means that I can write posts directly on google drive (I use markdown which google drive doesn't support). Enter stackedit, a web app that I can use from any online device. It lets you write markdown (even gives a live preview of the processed markdown) and save it to google drive. So, with any luck, this post is going to be saved from stackedit and it'll appear on my blog. Here we go!

Edit: It works!

entry.title: From postachio to pelican
entry.summary: I've got a bit fed up with the lack of control that I've had when using postachio, there's metadata that I want in my templates that I can't have. Despite promises that they were going to improve things toward the end of last year things have also gone a bit …
entry.content:
I've got a bit fed up with the lack of control that I've had when using postachio, there's metadata that I want in my templates that I can't have. Despite promises that they were going to improve things toward the end of last year things have also gone a bit quiet. For this reason I decided to move back to pelican. This was not as trivial as it maybe could have been. Getting evernote posts into markdown with the images where I wanted wasn't simple. However, pelican comes with pelican-import which can import posts from a rss feed into markdown. Postachio only puts the last 50 posts into the rss feed so I had to do an import, move posts into a different notebook, do an import etc...


Once I had that done I had to grab the images and put them in the right place. Luckily all of the posts in the rss appeared to have my images hosted on a postachio cdn. Using a simple regex I was able to write a script to locate image tags in the markdown files and then download the images from the urls. As a part of this the script also had to update the image url to be the new, correct, relative url. I also had to tweak pelican-import to look for published date rather than updated date in the feed.


Great, loads of markdown files and images. Next job, alter my old theme and then setup github pages. It's still far from being right but it's a start that'll do for now, I also need to create an automation process so that I don't have to manually publish, I'm not sure how I'll do that yet. It'd be easy if it wasn't for the images.


Anyway, new (kinda) site, woo! I also haven't forgotten photo a day. I'm still taking the photos but I want to work out my posting workflow before posting more as the images are a pain. Hopefully I'll get that nailed soon.

entry.title: Day 48 - photo a day
entry.summary: For a while now I've been looking at sleep trackers with an eye to try improve my sleep by working out ideal sleep lengths etc... I've been using sleep as android on my phone, which seems quite feature packed and I love the smart wakeup feature but I'm dubious about …
entry.content:
For a while now I've been looking at sleep trackers with an eye to try improve my sleep by working out ideal sleep lengths etc... I've been using sleep as android on my phone, which seems quite feature packed and I love the smart wakeup feature but I'm dubious about the tracking accuracy. I rarely sleep through the night and have to get up to go for a wee a few times, sleep as android doesn't ever seem to detect this as awake time. Understandable as the phone just lies on the bed so just sees a flurry of movement then stillness, another flurry then still again.

The very best trackers are upwards of 100 quid and even general fitness bands that also do sleep tracking tend to be \~£80 and a lot of them sleep tracking seems like a bit of an afterthought. The Jawbone UP3 appears on a few sleep tracker rundowns as one of the better bands for it, although it has a closed API so won't integrate with other apps and I think that it was recently bought out and the buyer said they won't be releasing any further updates (could be something else though). It does have smart wakeup and things like that though. Anyway, I found a seller on ebay selling the UP3 for £40 new but without packaging. £40 is just about the maximum that I've been willing to flutter on this as it's almost about interest as anything else. Being able to track the number of times I wake up during the night could prove useful though.

Today it arrived, it's reasonably small and seems pretty simple to use. Three LEDs show various things such as mode and various notifications. The app was pretty simple to setup and seems to have everything that I need, it also does things like step tracking and monitors heart rate. I'm not overly interested in step tracking, passive heart rate could be interesting though. Whilst the band doesn't actively monitor heart rate it does have what it calls passive monitoring. This means that it samples heart rate at various points during the day, this is supposed to assist with showing the effect of hydration, stress etc... on heart rate. It also works out resting heart rate by sampling heart rate when you wake up. I suspect once the novelty wears off I may stop wearing it during the day, we'll see. One other thing I really like is that you don't have to tell the app when you're going to sleep or wake up, it just detects it.

EDIT: After 1 night sleep it does appears to work quite well. I took note of the times I started to try to sleep and what time and I woke up and the tracker was pretty accurate on times. It monitored deep sleep, REM, light sleep and number of wake ups and time awake. 2h27m deep sleep, 3h5m light sleep, 1h14m REM, 39m awake (this is including a period of time where I just lay in bed and didn't really get up, it appears to show this period on the chart as awake too which is quite cool) and 2 wake ups. Obviously I have no idea how accurate the sleep lengths are, but the awake feels like it's about right and the wake ups is correct too. I've just noticed it tracks passive heart rate during sleep too and displays a chart of overnight heart rate and RHR across the week which is cool if you're a nerd for basically useless data like I am!

Although the tables are all in a row and the place is small you do still feel like you have your own space and some privacy. The toilet is also actually a completely different building - they use the public toilets a couple of buildings down! The food was fantastic, on the steep side price wise but worth it. I had fish soup and hake bake and those were both tasty, I probably could have just eaten the fish soup all night it was amazing. Anyway, here's a hake bake.

entry.title: Day 26 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: Lately I've been questioning if I eat enough calories during a normal day. I tend to just eat two (big) meals a day plus a bit of fruit as a snack once or twice too. I don't really like having breakfast early (as in before work) it makes my feel …
entry.content: Lately I've been questioning if I eat enough calories during a normal day. I tend to just eat two (big) meals a day plus a bit of fruit as a snack once or twice too. I don't really like having breakfast early (as in before work) it makes my feel a bit unwell and I don't really have time anyway as I'm pretty useless at getting out of bed. For this reason I decided to make some breakfast bars that I can just grab one of and eat whilst I'm putting together my flask of coffee. Trying to find a recipe actually wasn't as easy as I expected, due to needing it to be vegan and low fat. A lot of recipes seem to have coconut in them. In the end I went for http://www.ihcbesthealth.com/articles/baked-oatmeal-breakfast-bars-vegan/, although I replaced raisins with blueberries because ugh raisins. Due to my oven being quite rubbish I think that they could have done with being baked for a bit longer but that's something I know for next time.

entry.content: A pretty standard day really so not much exciting again. 2 litres of cold pressed flaxseed oil! I've frozen 1.75 litres of it as it doesn't keep for long. Why? That oms diet again, flaxseed oil is very high in omega 3 fats and they recommend 30-40ml a day of it. 2 litres cost me 50 quid so it's far from cheap but hopefully it'll be worth it in the long run. I'll probably use it to drizzle over food as well eating it straight from a spoon. The taste is nice, quite nutty, and it doesn't coat your mouth in a film like some other oils would do at least it's easy to take.

entry.title: Day 15 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary: I spent a fair bit of yesterday afternoon and most of today getting Unreal Editor 4 to run so there's no way it's not going to be my photo a day! I started out in fedora 24 and kept getting the error LLVM triggered Diagnostic Handler: unsupported call to function …
entry.content:
I spent a fair bit of yesterday afternoon and most of today getting Unreal Editor 4 to run so there's no way it's not going to be my photo a day! I started out in fedora 24 and kept getting the error LLVM triggered Diagnostic Handler: unsupported call to function exp10f in main, I wound up formatting and installing ubuntu and STILL got it.

That did not please me.

Whilst the editor would run the create/open project screen it'd bomb with that error in the logs when I tried to open or create a project. Anyway, that's jumping the gun a little.

Googling this issue didn't throw up a whole lot but one of the, few, hits hinted at graphics drivers. I have a radeon rx200 graphics card and it seems that the AMD proprietary drivers have been dropped in both fedora 24 and ubuntu 16.04+ (I'm using ubuntu-gnome 16.10). The open source drivers seem to be good enough though, I've been playing Heroes of the Storm through wine without issues. I spent a fair bit of time poking around my system and googling various things, I somehow got into looking at opengl. I saw that my system was using a version of mesa that gave me opengl 3. I saw that UE4 had an opengl4 flag so decided that it had to be worth a go as I was pretty sure the error was related to graphics. In the end I tracked down the Oibaf PPA which offered up a newer version of mesa and llvm. I thought that it looked promising and then came across this link on the epic games forums which validated it a bit so went for it. The step missing in that guide that I needed was to do an apt-get dist-upgrade. After doing that I rebooted and started UE4 again, created a project and hey! there we go, it works.
Here it is in all of its glory.

entry.title: Day 6 - photo a day 2017
entry.summary:
Today I received me some post! What I got was maybe a bit unusual; a vitamin d test kit. Why? I'll tell you why.

I bought the litmus paper because of a conversation I had with a colleague at my works christmas meal. We were chatting and I mentioned that …
entry.content:
Today I received me some post! What I got was maybe a bit unusual; a vitamin d test kit. Why? I'll tell you why.

I bought the litmus paper because of a conversation I had with a colleague at my works christmas meal. We were chatting and I mentioned that I have MS, he asked me if I'd ever tested my pH level - I had not. He went on to talk about body pH level and the importance of it and suggested I got some and tested myself. I figured nothing to lose, may as well take a look as it can't hurt to do so.

The vitamin d test, well I could waffle about this for quite a while but I won't. Long story short I've started following the overcomingms diet/lifestyle as quite a few people report good success with it. The book is quite compelling and it all appears to be evidence based, albeit case studies. As someone who knows not a lot about this stuff it's difficult to know but it's something to give me hope so I'm running with it. The importance of vitamin d levels in MS is stressed quite highly and, although I do already take 5000IU of vitamin d daily, I thought that I may as well get myself tested to find out what level I'm at. It's a pretty simple test, prick finger, dab blood in three spots and send off to an NHS clinic, simples.
